H.text: The Patriot Act is an anti-terrorism law.
H.ref: Critics of the USA Patriot Act called for the Senate to temper the anti-terrorism law's provisions that let police conduct secret searches of people's homes or businesses, but defenders say since no abuses have been documented the law should be renewed.

H.text: The powers in the Patriot Act last only four years.
H.ref: When Congress enacted the Patriot Act after the Sept. 11 attacks, it put the Justice Department on a short leash, mandating that many of the new powers in the act would last only four years unless renewed by Congress.

H.text: The Patriot Act provisions let police conduct secret searches of people's homes or businesses.
H.ref: Critics of the USA Patriot Act called for the Senate to temper the anti-terrorism law's provisions that let police conduct secret searches of people's homes or businesses, but defenders say since no abuses have been documented the law should be renewed.

H.text: Alberto Gonzales prepares his defense of expiring provisions of the Patriot Act.
H.ref: As Attorney General Alberto Gonzales prepares his defense of expiring provisions of the Patriot Act, the anti-terrorism law's opponents hope to persuade Congress not to extend what they say are intrusions into Americans' lives.

H.text: Alberto Gonzales shifts away from the hard-line of John Ashcroft.
H.ref: WASHINGTON - Attorney General Alberto Gonzales signaled Tuesday that the Bush administration is open to compromise with civil liberties advocates on key provisions of the USA Patriot Act as it comes up for renewal this year, shifting away from the hard-line stance of his predecessor, John Ashcroft.

H.text: Congress passed the Patriot Act after September 11, 2001.
H.ref: Congress passed the Patriot Act shortly after Sept. 11, 2001.

H.text: Critics of the Patriot Act want Congress to pass SAFE Act.
H.ref: Critics of the law want Congress to pass the SAFE Act to limit the Patriot Act in several ways, including requiring government officials to inform suspects about the "sneak and peek" searches within seven days if a judge does not intervene.

H.text: The Patriot Act comes up for renewal in 2005.
H.ref: WASHINGTON - Attorney General Alberto Gonzales signaled Tuesday that the Bush administration is open to compromise with civil liberties advocates on key provisions of the USA Patriot Act as it comes up for renewal this year, shifting away from the hard-line stance of his predecessor, John Ashcroft.

H.text: Many sections of the Patriot Act expire on December 31, 2005.
H.ref: PRUNING THE PATRIOT ACTCONGRESS APPROVED the USA Patriot Act in a flush of fear following the Sept. 11 attacks in 2001, but it had the good sense to put a time limit on many of the most controversial sections so they expire next Dec. 31.

H.text: Alberto Gonzales defends renewal of the Patriot Act to Congress.
H.ref: Attorney general to defend renewal of Patriot Act to Congress

H.text: FBI agents have used the Patriot Act search warrants.
H.ref: And Gonzales disclosed that FBI agents have used Patriot Act search warrants 35 times to obtain business records deemed relevant to a terrorism investigation.

H.text: Justice Department investigators used powers allowed under the Patriot Act.
H.ref: WASHINGTON - Justice Department investigators nearly doubled the rate at which they used a controversial new search-and-seizure power, allowed under the USA PATRIOT Act, during the past 22 months, according to data released by the Bush administration Monday on the eve of congressional testimony by Attorney General Alberto Gonzales.

H.text: John Ashcroft is the predecessor of Alberto Gonzales.
H.ref: WASHINGTON - Attorney General Alberto Gonzales signaled Tuesday that the Bush administration is open to compromise with civil liberties advocates on key provisions of the USA Patriot Act as it comes up for renewal this year, shifting away from the hard-line stance of his predecessor, John Ashcroft.

H.text: Congress put a time limit on many sections of the Patriot Act.
H.ref: PRUNING THE PATRIOT ACTCONGRESS APPROVED the USA Patriot Act in a flush of fear following the Sept. 11 attacks in 2001, but it had the good sense to put a time limit on many of the most controversial sections so they expire next Dec. 31.

H.text: The Patriot Act has aroused civil liberties concerns.
H.ref: The Bush administration wants Congress to make permanent all 15 provisions of the law that expire at the end of the year, some of which have aroused civil liberties concerns among liberals and conservatives.

H.text: The Bush administration is open to compromise with civil liberties advocates.
H.ref: WASHINGTON - Attorney General Alberto Gonzales signaled Tuesday that the Bush administration is open to compromise with civil liberties advocates on key provisions of the USA Patriot Act as it comes up for renewal this year, shifting away from the hard-line stance of his predecessor, John Ashcroft.

H.text: Montana joined four states that have passed resolutions.
H.ref: Last week, Montana joined four other states that have passed resolutions urging Congress to curb the new powers hastily granted to federal law enforcement agencies six weeks after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.

H.text: The Bush administration wants Congress to make permanent all provisions of the Patriot Act that expire in 2005.
H.ref: The Bush administration wants Congress to make permanent all 15 provisions of the law that expire at the end of the year, some of which have aroused civil liberties concerns among liberals and conservatives.

H.text: The Bush administration launched its campaign to preserve the Patriot Act.
H.ref: The Bush Administration launched its campaign to preserve and expand the USA Patriot Act, the much-debated anti-terrorism legislation enacted after Sept. 11.

H.text: The Bush administration launched its campaign to expand the Patriot Act.
H.ref: The Bush Administration launched its campaign to preserve and expand the USA Patriot Act, the much-debated anti-terrorism legislation enacted after Sept. 11.

H.text: Alberto Gonzales will testify before the Senate Judiciary Committee.
H.ref: Attorney General Alberto Gonzales will begin making the administration's case to Congress this week, testifying before the Senate Judiciary Committee on Tuesday and the House Judiciary Committee on Wednesday.

H.text: Alberto Gonzales will testify before the House Judiciary Committee.
H.ref: Attorney General Alberto Gonzales will begin making the administration's case to Congress this week, testifying before the Senate Judiciary Committee on Tuesday and the House Judiciary Committee on Wednesday.
